subject: Log message when debug is enabled
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-09-22 00:46:56.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/server/common.py'], 'message': 'Log message when debug is enabled

Operators may not realize that when debug is enabled that keystone
will return extra, potentially sensitive, data in error responses.

Operators should at least be warned that this will happen.

SecurityImpact

Change-Id: I82d00898ee2b28aad1ace7554a436cf7125d631c
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Log message when debug is enabled

Operators may not realize that when debug is enabled that keystone
will return extra, potentially sensitive, data in error responses.

Operators should at least be warned that this will happen.

SecurityImpact

Change-Id: I82d00898ee2b28aad1ace7554a436cf7125d631c

commit_message:
Tempest: use mkdtemp to make temp directories

generate_random_name() was used instead of mkdtemp to create temporary
directories, with no check on existence. This fixes that.

Change-Id: I69c49e146ef1edca2b6fac0c0a9a06e158db160c

commit_message:
Raise container deployment timeout

If yum repository configuration is partially broken,
it will delay deployment time. The time should be
raised to match the dockerctl timeout of 400s.

Change-Id: Icc68f039362d7c3f08c532add14d24f2140b8e3d
Closes-Bug: #1494640

revisions:

Closes-Bug: #1496931
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2015-09-17 17:05:05.000000000', 'files': ['ansible/roles/nova/templates/nova.conf.j2'], 'message': 'Add missing libvirt section to nova.conf

This is required to boot VMs using Nova. Add a sane default to the

Closes-Bug: #1496931
', 'number': 2}]
commit_message:
Add missing libvirt section to nova.conf

This is required to boot VMs using Nova. Add a sane default to the
template to suit most, and make it easier for those who want something
else to see where to override.

Change-Id: I898862b905289cc30ad447f0ef81895c93ff2478
Closes-Bug: #1496931

commit_message:
Enable back cover job

Rally 'cover' tox job runs against last two commits so, fix for
broken cover job was implemented with disabled job.
Now we need to enable it.

Change-Id: Id083b233ae072fa8e0a875dee74a33c6a3f51ec8
Partial-Bug: #1497897

mirror to use. Add this ability.

commit_message:
add ironic support:

 * Add new network 'ironic'
 * Add new role 'ironic_slave'. This VM looks like
   current 'slave' node, but it is connected ONLY
   to "ironic" network.
 * fix Node.interface_by_name method. Rename it to
   interface_by_network_name

Partially Implements: blueprint integrate-ironic-to-test-tools

Change-Id: Idd9ebca53c2cfd0df088c7d516f6285ad58fe7db

commit_message:
Parameter osapi_max_limit is always used by default

Default value max_limit is initialized before a value is read from
the config file. Default parameter values are always evaluated when
the “def” statement they belong to is executed. So parameter
osapi_max_limit is always used by default even it's set in the
configuration file.

Change-Id: I1414667d30e98b56c5eb1b09b802bab823b37e2d
Closes-Bug: #1487510

commit_message:
Using OpenStack CLI for supporting Keystone V3

Currently python-keystoneclient focuses on python API only and
python-openstackclient on CLI. This is certain trend now (ask from
keystone guys). So to enable more new features for example keystone v3
here, we need use openstackclient in devstack install scripts.

Notes:
python API means:
    # python scripts
    from keystoneclient import client as c
    c.Client(...).get_user_list(...)

CLI means:
    # bash/shell scripts
    keystone user-list

Closed-Bug: #1478763
Change-Id: Iee802c887994da7036fe206c1b2970c1006e273c

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-09-18 20:29:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Relax service module check on service providers

service_provider is a 'special' configuration. It is a MultiStr
option that used to be in neutron.conf, but moved into its own *-aas
config files after the service split. We allow for the definition to
be available 'anywhere': either in neutron.conf or in the *-aas
service's config file.

The list of 'service_provider' can include drivers from within the *-aas
tree, or from elsewhere, and can apply to different service types. Due to
the polymorphic nature of this variable it is very tricky to identify only
the drivers that pertain a specific service module: the service module
may as well implement more than one service type and may have support
from drivers out of tree.

For this reason it is best to relax this check and rely on query filters
when the ServiceManager.get_service_providers() is invoked.

Closes-bug: #1492069

Change-Id: I4db4ce0b287c984d86181227edf769531ecb7bb8
", 'number': 1}, {'created': '2015-09-18 20:37:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Relax service module check on service providers

service_provider is a 'special' configuration. It is a MultiStr
option that used to be in neutron.conf, but moved into its own *-aas
config files after the service split. We allow for the definition to
be available 'anywhere': either in neutron.conf or in the *-aas
service's config file.

The list of 'service_provider' can include drivers from within the *-aas
tree, or from elsewhere, and can apply to different service types. Due to
the polymorphic nature of this variable it is very tricky to identify only
the drivers that pertain a specific service module: the service module
may as well implement more than one service type and may have support
from drivers out of tree.

For this reason it is best to relax this check and rely on query filters
when the ServiceManager.get_service_providers() is invoked. Furthermore,
without this fix there was a situation where the value returned by
'service_providers' may be differ depending on how the configuration is
passed on the CLI, and this inconsistency may only cause headaches.

Closes-bug: #1492069

commit_message:
Relax service module check on service providers

service_provider is a 'special' configuration. It is a MultiStr
option that used to be in neutron.conf, but moved into its own *-aas
config files after the service split. We allow for the definition to
be available 'anywhere': either in neutron.conf or in the *-aas
service's config file.

The list of 'service_provider' can include drivers from within the *-aas
tree, or from elsewhere, and can apply to different service types. Due to
the polymorphic nature of this variable it is very tricky to identify only
the drivers that pertain a specific service module: the service module
may as well implement more than one service type and may have support
from drivers out of tree.

For this reason it is best to relax this check and rely on query filters
when the ServiceManager.get_service_providers() is invoked. Furthermore,
without this fix there was a situation where the value returned by
'service_providers' may be differ depending on how the configuration is
passed on the CLI, and this inconsistency may only cause headaches.

Closes-bug: #1492069

Change-Id: I4db4ce0b287c984d86181227edf769531ecb7bb8

commit_message:

This change includes README.rst directly into the base index.rst rather
than including it by reference in readme.rst and removes readme.rst from
the ToC. It also expands on the introductory paragraph in preparation for
linking to the top level index.html from the parent OpenStack developer

subject: Fix leaking environment variables in tests
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-09-21 16:08:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Fix leaking environment variables in tests.

In rspec provider tests the environment variables are used to
authenticate the calls.  The environment was set in a shared example.
The problem is that rspec read all those environment variables when it
compile the tests.  Then the last shared environment red by rspec was
setting the environment for all the test.  This was leading to
unpredictable behavior.

This fix this problem by setting the environment variables before each
test at rspec run time.

Change-Id: I28c952273d6f981c953cb3e2c960a98609ece263
Closes-Bug: 1482243

commit_message:
Fix leaking environment variables in tests

In rspec provider tests the environment variables are used to
authenticate the calls.  The environment was set in a shared example.
The problem is that rspec read all those environment variables when it
compile the tests.  Then the last shared environment red by rspec was
setting the environment for all the test.  This was leading to
unpredictable behavior.

This fix this problem by setting the environment variables before each
test at rspec run time.

Change-Id: I28c952273d6f981c953cb3e2c960a98609ece263
Closes-Bug: 1482243

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-09-18 20:06:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Get rid of ConfigParser code in ProviderConfiguration

We may be unable to get rid of this code, but at least we can
make it slimmer and more oslo_config friendly.

This patch also fixes an issue where plain ConfigParser cannot

commit_message:
Get rid of ConfigParser code in ProviderConfiguration

We may be unable to get rid of this code, but at least we can
make it slimmer and more oslo_config friendly.

This patch also fixes an issue where plain ConfigParser cannot
handle config options with the same name under same section.

Related-bug: #1492069

Change-Id: I596613eb7b2fc3e894a3c1cc7b7cb24d7137cbc5

subject: Update load balancers after HOT autoscaling event
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-04 01:51:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Update load balancers after HOT autoscaling event

This change adds the ability to update load balancers after an
autoscaling event is triggered on the OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup
resource in HOT templates. This feature is currently available only on
the AWS::AutoScaling::AutoScalingGroup and OS::Heat::InstanceGroup
resources.

To implement this feature the following changes have been
made:

- Add "load_balancer_names" property to the OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup
  resource, similar to "LoadBalancerNames" in InstanceGroup.
- Allow custom load balancer resources to be included in the
  "load_balancer_names" list. This is done so that regular instances
  running HAProxy or similar load balancers can also be updated after
  the ASG resizes. These custom resources are then able to get the
  updated list of instances through a get_attr call.

Closes-Bug: #1437524
Change-Id: Ib11f29e24e11fba93b59e39e5007f1b6c2814ec6

commit_message:
Update load balancers after HOT autoscaling event

This change adds the ability to update load balancers after an
autoscaling event is triggered on the OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup
resource in HOT templates. This feature is currently available only on
the AWS::AutoScaling::AutoScalingGroup and OS::Heat::InstanceGroup
resources.

To implement this feature the following changes have been
made:

- Add "load_balancer_names" property to the OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup
  resource, similar to "LoadBalancerNames" in InstanceGroup.
- Allow custom load balancer resources to be included in the
  "load_balancer_names" list. This is done so that regular instances
  running HAProxy or similar load balancers can also be updated after
  the ASG resizes. These custom resources are then able to get the
  updated list of instances through a get_attr call.

Closes-Bug: #1437524
Change-Id: Ib11f29e24e11fba93b59e39e5007f1b6c2814ec6

commit_message:
Initial support for database clustering in Horizon

Added a separate panel for clusters.

This panel contains the Clusters Table with table actions to
Launch and Terminate clusters.  There are row actions Add Shard
and Reset Password (and their associated dialogs) that are specific
to MongoDB and Vertica respectively.

The Clusters Details will include the following tabs:
- Overview
- Instances (table of instances belonging to this cluster)

The launch panel has custom fields for MongoDB and Vertica.
The custom fields will be dynamically shown based on the datastore
selected.

Added a db_capability utility to aid in identifying the specific
datastores.

Added network selection dropdown if neutron is enabled.

Co-Authored-By: Sushil Kumar <sushil.kumar3@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Saurabh Surana <saurabh.surana@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Duk Loi <duk@tesora.com>
Co-Authored-By: Anna Shen <ruiyuan.shen@hp.com>
Change-Id: I047f4d37449070adfd0ea66ad010982f35c049aa
Implements: blueprint database-clustering-support

Implements bp docstring-improvements

subject: Template-validate fails when resources are swaped with None resource
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-09-15 11:16:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Template-validate fails when resources are swaped with None resource

validate_template() in service.py is trying to validate the
properties mentioned in the template using the Resource plugin
class. This fails as None resource plugin properties are always
empty.

Fix is added to skip the NoneResource validation appropriately.

Change-Id: I3e9e0ee69b863c1cadcff78eed822e3c3a75fbf6

commit_message:
Template-validate fails when resources are swaped with None resource

validate_template() in service.py is trying to validate the
properties mentioned in the template using the Resource plugin
class. This fails as None resource plugin properties are always
empty.

Fix is added to skip the NoneResource validation appropriately.
TemplateResource also made adhere to same logic.

Change-Id: I3e9e0ee69b863c1cadcff78eed822e3c3a75fbf6
Closes-Bug: #1495914

commit_message:
WiP Only get host data for floating ips on DVR routers

First, we should only be interested in setting the host
attributed whet the router is a DVR router (this may need to be
vetted).  Second, we don't need to query all of the ports on the host,
we just need to query the ports that are referenced by the set of
floating ips that we already have.

Don't merge this.  The original patch has not been merged yet.

Signed-off-by: Ryan Moats <rmoats@us.ibm.com>
Closes-bug: #1496974
(cherry picked from commit 3999409b8c07f7cca9a27fd53aa8ca81cfa64028)

Change-Id: I955a10e135bba9011e68ec6b26d27d82ab2d3410

commit_message:
Add a functional test proving OS::Heat::None works with validate

Previously the template-validate logic failed when overriding
resources with OS::Heat::None in the resource_registry, despite
this working fine via create/preview.

Since the fix for bug #1467573 has aligned the template-validate
logic with that of create/preview, this should now work.

Change-Id: Id8d0be57d347e7ef6714477747949bd2dadd470c
Closes-Bug: #1495914

commit_message:
Migrate to Kubernetes Release 1

Kubernetes Release 1.0 was announced at OSCON

A new Fedora Atomic image has been built with version 1.0.4 and
this series of patches will update the templates, scripts, documents
to work with the new image.

The api has also been changed from v1beta3 to v1 and the beta
api is no longer available, so the interface between Magnum and
Kubernetes master are updated as well in this series of patches.

This particular patch will bring up a V1 cluster with the
bay-create command.  Because the switch to the V1 API requires
all the code changes to be applied at once, this patch pulls
in portion of 3 patches together.  The changes include:

1. devstack plugin downloads the new image.

2. k8s conductor and other code calls the new V1 client and
k8s methods.

3. Configuration for k8s services and docker updated with
new parameters.

4. Minion registration and example code updated to V1.

5. Functional tests updated to V1.

6. Gate test setup points to the new image.

Co-Authored-By: Hongbin Lu <hongbin.lu@huawei.com>

Change-Id: I046931ad491e8b7ee45943852901eac5c3df913e
Partially-Implements: blueprint kubernetes-v1

subject: test_dashboard_basic_ops: handle urllib2 exceptions in check_login_page
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-09-22 03:59:34.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/scenario/test_dashboard_basic_ops.py'], 'message': 'test_dashboard_basic_ops: handle urllib2 exceptions in check_login_page

The first HTTP request is done by check_login_page.
This patch aims to try the request and handle exceptions to define
why a request would fail, by giving message and http return code.

Change-Id: If38b5d7e9dd47af87d0b678eac0506243361e852
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
test_dashboard_basic_ops: handle urllib2 exceptions in check_login_page

The first HTTP request is done by check_login_page.
This patch aims to try the request and handle exceptions to define
why a request would fail, by giving message and http return code.

Change-Id: If38b5d7e9dd47af87d0b678eac0506243361e852

commit_message:
enhance nova list output with new three fields

Nova list to accept a new parameter --maximal.
Using --maximal option we can have three new fields.
These three new files are
flavor-name
availability-zone-list
image-name

Change-Id: Idf55af5999a323996c7e5f1581901ab4a4174eed

commit_message:
Validates baymodel network_driver requests

Instead of allowing any network_driver value to be accepted by
the baymodel API, this patch limits the value to "flannel". As
additional network drivers get merged, the validation will be
expanded.

Co-Authored-By: Dane LeBlanc <leblancd@cisco.com>
Partially-Implements: blueprint extend-baymodel-net-attributes

Change-Id: I62397f30d08d3d684285cdc9d94a6f5b7d509940

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-04-28 20:01:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Add DB2 support

General: I've made this one big patch rather than several patches
in a series because the thinking is we're either going to merge
all of the DB2 support together or none of it at all. This also
helps with the 3rd party CI testing so it can just run tests on
this patch until the code is merged. I've outlined the details below
for reviewing the change.

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. The lack
   of foreign keys has not presented any functional issues. A possible
   solution is a future patch which makes the instances.uuid column
   non-nullable but that presents it's own difficulties and is outside
   the scope of this change.

2. The ibm_db_sa DB URI in test_migrations.conf is non-standard due to
   how it must be formed to work with the IBM DB2 ODBC/CLI driver.

3. TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR is bumped since the scaling factor of 2 wasn't
   keeping up with the tests on an m1.medium instance used for testing.

4. Schemas are used rather than databases for the tests since the
   create/drop of those are significantly faster in DB2.

Other changes:

1. Handle the 'ibm_db_sa' sqlalchemy engine in the modify_indexes
   utility method.

2. Sync commit 8dccc7b "Handle ibm_db_sa DBDuplicateEntry integrity
   errors" from oslo-incubator. This is needed for 3rd party CI to pass
   for DB2 against Tempest negative tests that rely on duplicate entries
   failing and being handled in the DB API layer. This is not a full
   of the oslo db module since:
   (a) that would pull in far more than is needed here
   (b) oslo db hasn't been synced to Nova since July of 2013 so it would
       not be trivial
   (c) Mirantis is already working on syncing oslo db to Nova but it
       will probably be awhile before that lands.

Implements blueprint db2-database
Closes-Bug: #1227321

Change-Id: Ic4224e2545bcdfeb236b071642f9f16d9ee3b99f

', 'number': 2}, {'created': '2014-04-28 20:01:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "WIP: Add DB2 support

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. To create
   the foreign keys on instances.uuid I've added migration 245 to drop
   any records where instances.uuid == None (and related tables where
   instance_uuid == None, except for fixed_ips - details inline) so we
   can make instances.uuid non-nullable and create a unique constraint
   on instances.uuid, then new migration 246 creates the missing
   instances.uuid related foreign keys for DB2. There was some mailing
   list discussion about making instances.uuid non-nullable and is
   further discussed in the related nova-spec.

2. The ibm_db_sa DB URI in test_migrations.conf is non-standard due to
   how it must be formed to work with the IBM DB2 ODBC/CLI driver.

3. TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR is bumped since the scaling factor of 2 wasn't
   keeping up with the tests on an m1.medium instance used for testing.

4. Schemas are used rather than databases for the tests since the
   create/drop of those are significantly faster in DB2.

Implements blueprint db2-database

", 'number': 20}, {'created': '2014-04-28 20:01:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "WIP: Add DB2 support

General: I've made this one big patch rather than several patches
in a series because the thinking is we're either going to merge
all of the DB2 support together or none of it at all. This also
helps with the 3rd party CI testing so it can just run tests on
this patch until the code is merged. I've outlined the details below
for reviewing the change.

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. To create
   the foreign keys on instances.uuid I've added migration 245 to drop
   any records where instances.uuid == None (and related tables where
   instance_uuid == None, except for fixed_ips - details inline) so we
   can make instances.uuid non-nullable and create a unique constraint
   on instances.uuid, then new migration 246 creates the missing
   instances.uuid related foreign keys for DB2. There was some mailing
   list discussion about making instances.uuid non-nullable and is
   further discussed in the related nova-spec.

2. The ibm_db_sa DB URI in test_migrations.conf is non-standard due to
   how it must be formed to work with the IBM DB2 ODBC/CLI driver.

3. TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR is bumped since the scaling factor of 2 wasn't
   keeping up with the tests on an m1.medium instance used for testing.

4. Schemas are used rather than databases for the tests since the
   create/drop of those are significantly faster in DB2.

Implements blueprint db2-database

Change-Id: Ic4224e2545bcdfeb236b071642f9f16d9ee3b99f

   regressed in the scheam for mysql/postgresql? schema_diff
   manual run with attached output or check in sql dumps and
   write a unit test to compare to those?

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. To create
   the foreign keys on instances.uuid, this change depends on commit
   e07a2b2d4be0503ad8dad75daa632be27cf83320 to make instances.uuid
   non-nullable and create a unique constraint on that column. Then

   keeping up with the tests on an m1.medium instance used for testing.

4. Schemas are used rather than databases for the tests since the
   create/drop of those are significantly faster in DB2.

5. The 247_nullable_mismatch migration is updated for DB2 because
   making the pci_devices.deleted column nullable=True fails since
   the column is in a UniqueConstraint already (DB2 would require
   it to be in a unique index instead for the column to be nullable).

", 'number': 40}, {'created': '2015-01-31 01:43:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Add DB2 support

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. To create
   the foreign keys on instances.uuid, this change depends on commit
   e07a2b2d4be0503ad8dad75daa632be27cf83320 to make instances.uuid
   non-nullable and create a unique constraint on that column. Then
   the new migration here creates the missing instances.uuid
   related foreign keys for DB2.

2. Commit b930fb3a6b0ab8cbe0c19eb3ab8ba33d60d147be changed
   test_migrations.py to use oslo.db's opportunistic test fixture
   which currently only supports sqlite/mysql/postgresql. Unit test
   support for DB2 therefore needs to be added to oslo.db and then
   hooked into nova, but that's targeted for the 2015.2 'L' release
   so is not part of this change.

3. The 247_nullable_mismatch migration is updated for DB2 because
   making the pci_devices.deleted column nullable=True fails since
   the column is in a UniqueConstraint already (DB2 would require
   it to be in a unique index instead for the column to be nullable).
   There is a foreign key involved (created in 246) so for DB2 to
   have the same FKey it requires a UC and that requires the deleted
   column to be non-null, which doesn't work with the SoftDeleteMixin.
   So in this case the schema will diverge for DB2 until we make
   the deleted column non-nullable for all tables.

4. The 252_add_instance_extra_table migration is updated for DB2
   because a foreign key is created between the instance_extra
   table and the instances.uuid column (which is nullable at the
   time) so we have to handle that foreign key constraint creation
   in the 273 migration with the other foreign keys to
   instances.uuid.

5. The 271 migration is updated to add ibm_db_sa the same as
   sqlite and postgresql since it works the same in this case for
   DB2.

Implements blueprint db2-database

   table and the instances.uuid column (which is nullable at the
   time) so we have to handle that foreign key constraint creation
   in the 296 migration with the other foreign keys to
   instances.uuid.

5. The 271 migration is updated to add ibm_db_sa the same as
   sqlite and postgresql since it works the same in this case for
   DB2.

Implements blueprint db2-database

commit_message:
Add DB2 support

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. To create
   the foreign keys on instances.uuid, this change depends on commit
   e07a2b2d4be0503ad8dad75daa632be27cf83320 to make instances.uuid
   non-nullable and create a unique constraint on that column. Then
   the new migration here creates the missing instances.uuid
   related foreign keys for DB2.

2. Commit b930fb3a6b0ab8cbe0c19eb3ab8ba33d60d147be changed
   test_migrations.py to use oslo.db's opportunistic test fixture
   which currently only supports sqlite/mysql/postgresql. Unit test
   support for DB2 therefore needs to be added to oslo.db and then
   hooked into nova, but that's targeted for the 2016.1 'M' release
   so is not part of this change.

3. The 247_nullable_mismatch migration is updated for DB2 because
   making the pci_devices.deleted column nullable=True fails since
   the column is in a UniqueConstraint already (DB2 would require
   it to be in a unique index instead for the column to be nullable).
   There is a foreign key involved (created in 246) so for DB2 to
   have the same FKey it requires a UC and that requires the deleted
   column to be non-null, which doesn't work with the SoftDeleteMixin.
   So in this case the schema will diverge for DB2 until we make
   the deleted column non-nullable for all tables.

4. The 252_add_instance_extra_table migration is updated for DB2
   because a foreign key is created between the instance_extra
   table and the instances.uuid column (which is nullable at the
   time) so we have to handle that foreign key constraint creation
   in the 296 migration with the other foreign keys to
   instances.uuid.

5. The 271 migration is updated to add ibm_db_sa the same as
   sqlite and postgresql since it works the same in this case for
   DB2.

6. The API migrations need checks for DB2 to avoid a duplicate index
   SQL0605W error since DB2 implicitly creates an Index when a
   UniqueConstraint is created and will fail if trying to add a
   duplicate index on the same column(s) that are in the UC.

Implements blueprint db2-database

Change-Id: Ic4224e2545bcdfeb236b071642f9f16d9ee3b99f

commit_message:
Use normal API not token/endpoint for image uploads

There is no reason to use keystone token bootstrapping for image
uploads. Glance is a service, and images can be uploaded to it normally
without special shenanigans.

Depends-On: If7b81c4a6746c8a1eb0302c96e045fb0f457d67b
Change-Id: I7092fb10cbe243e091789134263fab081af0c7f4

commit_message:
Move writing of credentials earlier in the process

If something goes wrong after keystone is running with services
registered, but before credentials are written, it's hard to poke at the
existing half-running state because none of the auth information is
recorded.

Write the files right after we're done bootstrapping keystone.

Change-Id: I2f8ae86e17d26ec4defa16e843faa8987d27fac9

commit_message:
Prevent extraneous log messages and stdout prints

while running unit tests using run_tests.sh,
we can see quite an amount of unwanted log
messages and stdout prints as part of
the unit test results on the console.
This basically makes it difficult to go
through the test results and figure whats happening.

This patch fixes the cause for those
extraneous log messages caused due to
a incorrect fixture usage in test_manage.py
and also by mocking sys.stdout at the respective unit tests.

Closes-bug: #1496898
Change-Id: If986691cb3f36ba357a5c0df34b6df7bf2d8ff86

subject: Fixed an HTTP 500 on artifact blob upload
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-08-24 10:36:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Fixed an HTTP 500 on artifact blob upload

If the HTTP PUT request to upload a binary file to an artifact does not
contain a Content-size header, the length of the binary file should be
detected during the upload.

However, the unset content size variable was leading to an exception as
its value (None) participates in some math operations during the upload.
Setting the value to 0 (same is v2 API) fixes the issue.

Closes-Bug: #1488037
FastTrack

commit_message:
Fixed an HTTP 500 on artifact blob upload

If the HTTP PUT request to upload a binary file to an artifact does not
contain a Content-size header, the length of the binary file should be
detected during the upload.

However, the unset content size variable was leading to an exception as
its value (None) participates in some math operations during the upload.
Setting the value to 0 (same is v2 API) fixes the issue.

Closes-Bug: #1488037
FastTrack

Change-Id: Iadbd97899445b58c2c5bad961bca61cd6ab60d1a

commit_message:
Add documentation for configuring IdP WebSSO

We recently added a new federation call to Keystone that will allow federated
authentication flows for a specific Identity Provider. This commit adds
documentation around configuring httpd modules for the newly added call and
horizon configuration.

Co-Authored-By: Lin Hua Cheng <os.lcheng@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Id334e979c951387b1d70da70fc5d4939a6e7d6a6
related: bp federation-idp-websso
Closes-Bug: 1491910
Related-Bug: 1491916

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-01-22 15:29:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Skip nodes that does not support REPLICATE verb

Alternative DiskFile backend implementations may not support or
implement REPLICATE verb. This change allows object replicator to
recognize such object servers and "black list" them and not send
further REPLICATE requests. This "black list" is cleared at
beginning of every replicator pass. Hence, each object server that
does not support REPLICATE verb will at the most be contacted once per
pass.

This change assumes that DiskFile implementations return either a
HTTPNotImplemented (501) or HTTPMethodNotAllowed (405).

Change-Id: I267808be88a025aaa8ce05ba63c15169ac18df9e
Signed-off-by: Prashanth Pai <ppai@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Skip nodes that does not support REPLICATE verb

Alternative DiskFile backend implementations may not support or
implement REPLICATE verb. This change allows object replicator to
recognize such object servers and "black list" them and not send
further REPLICATE requests. This "black list" is cleared at
beginning of every replicator pass. Hence, each object server that
does not support REPLICATE verb will at the most be contacted once per
pass.

This change assumes that DiskFile implementations return
HTTPNotImplemented (501).

Change-Id: I267808be88a025aaa8ce05ba63c15169ac18df9e
Signed-off-by: Prashanth Pai <ppai@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-08-28 16:15:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Fixed non-owner write-access to artifacts

There was no check for write-access priviledges during all the
mutating operations with artifacts (updates, patches, deletes,
actiovations etc), so any user who has an access to an artifact could
modify it. Because of this, non-owners could modify public artifacts
which was a major security issue.

Now this is addressed and an appropriate set of tests added to
prevent possible regressions.

Change-Id: I2f4c2d70b74ae39ababed2ba9b97559ef5ea6d6c
Closes-bug: #1489902

commit_message:
Fixed non-owner write-access to artifacts

There was no check for write-access priviledges during all the
mutating operations with artifacts (updates, patches, deletes,
actiovations etc), so any user who has an access to an artifact could
modify it. Because of this, non-owners could modify public artifacts
which was a major security issue.

Now this is addressed and an appropriate set of tests added to
prevent possible regressions.

FastTrack
Change-Id: I2f4c2d70b74ae39ababed2ba9b97559ef5ea6d6c
Closes-bug: #1489902

commit_message:
tests: don't validate respawn as part of ovsdb monitor functional test

It's already validated by AsyncProcess functional test suite. Instead,
just validate that the monitor generates the initial output, as
expected.

The test is still useful to validate that rootwrap filter works, so
not removing it completely.

Change-Id: I320edaaa2b210e4b34678c60deb31c4875eea298
Closes-Bug: #1495937

Those methods do the same thing as AsyncProcess counterparts, just with logging
the received output. It's better to move the logging into AsyncProcess and
control it with __init__ arguments.

commit_message:
ovsdb monitor: get rid of custom _read_stdout/_read_stderr methods

Those methods do the same thing as AsyncProcess counterparts, just
with logging the received output. It's better to move the logging into
AsyncProcess and control it with __init__ arguments.

This allows us to get rid of some duplicate tests for ovsdb monitor.

Change-Id: Ic20ded27ba09afdd73e4d96c47469c2d7b4d4db5
Related-Bug: #1495937

subject: Add neutron_migrations_facts module
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-09-02 16:03:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "[WIP] Remove unnecessary tasks in neutron_db_setup.yml

Doing the initial check for existing migrations is pointless -- we can
just run the same DB upgrade tasks irrespective of whether or not we've
already run an upgrade.  Note that this change does replace
neutron_db_revision user variable with neutron_db_expand_revision and
neutron_db_contract_revision since specifying just neutron_db_revision
isn't optimal when we have two branches and can run migrations on each
branch individually.

If there is no value in allowing the DB revision to be specified,
please let me know and I'll just hardcode to head.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1486593
Change-Id: Ie0c5cb5abff61d11b7a9278de6771fa008b69218

", 'number': 2}, {'created': '2015-09-10 10:20:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "More changes to neutron db migrations

This change does the following:

1. Adds user variables and neutron_db_expand_revision and
   neutron_db_contract_revision to replace neutron_db_revision (this is
   necessary since we now have two alembic branches, not one)
2. Runs the initial neutron-db-manage current without grep'ing so we
   can fail if that does not return an exit code of 0 (this is safer,
   as previously an exit code of 1 would go undetected due to the piped
   grep)
3. Updates the grep on the stdout from above to be more precise; neutron
   revision IDs seem to have a lenght ranging from 4 to 12
4. Changes the initial db sync to just doing --expand, which can be
   done whether or not migrations have previously run (this also
   removes the hard-coded reference to 'heads', which may have had
   unintended side-effects if someone specified a different revision)
5. Changes all neutron-db-manage upgrade tasks to use the specified
   revision

If there is no value in allowing the DB revision to be specified,
please let me know and I'll just hardcode to head instead.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1486593
Change-Id: Ie0c5cb5abff61d11b7a9278de6771fa008b69218

", 'number': 4}, {'created': '2015-09-10 12:00:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "More changes to neutron db migrations

This change does the following:

1. Adds user variables and neutron_db_expand_revision and
   neutron_db_contract_revision to replace neutron_db_revision (this is
   necessary since we now have two alembic branches, not one)
2. Runs the initial neutron-db-manage current without grep'ing so we
   can fail if that does not return an exit code of 0 (this is safer,
   as previously an exit code of 1 would go undetected due to the piped
   grep)
3. Creates a new task to parse the output of the above and sets a fact
   if a match is found (this indicates migrations have previously run)
4. Removes the initial db sync task since this is no longer needed
5. Updates the expand task to use the specified revision and runs it
   regardless of whether or not migrations have already been run
6. Similar to above, contract now uses the specified revision and also
   runs regardless, however guards are in place to only stop/start
   neutron-server on a brownfield deploy (doing this on a greenfield
   deploy will fail since the neutron-server service hasn't been
   fully configured/started)

If there is no value in allowing the DB revision to be specified,
please let me know and I'll just hardcode to head instead.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1486593
Change-Id: Ie0c5cb5abff61d11b7a9278de6771fa008b69218

", 'number': 7}, {'created': '2015-09-11 09:05:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Add neutron_migrations_facts module

This change does the following:

1. Adds neutron_migrations_facts module, which creates a fact
   with the state of each neutron alembic migration branch
2. Removes the migration check task since this is now handled by the
   neutron_migrations_facts module

   neutron_db_contract_revision to replace neutron_db_revision (this is
   necessary since we now have two alembic branches, not one)
4. Updates the upgrade tasks to work with a specific revision and only
   executes these tasks if the branch is not on head
5. Updates roles/os_neutron/tasks/main.yml so the init scripts are
   dropped before we handle db syncing, which means we can stop the
   neutron-server on a greenfield deploy

If there is no value in allowing the DB revision to be specified,
please let me know and I'll just hardcode to head instead.

commit_message:
Add neutron_migrations_facts module

This change does the following:

1. Adds neutron_migrations_facts module, which creates a fact
   with the state of each neutron alembic migration branch
2. Removes var neutron_db_revision since this is no longer used
3. Removes the migration check task since this is now handled by the
   neutron_migrations_facts module
4. Updates roles/os_neutron/tasks/main.yml so the init scripts are
   dropped before we handle db syncing, which means we can stop the
   neutron-server on a greenfield deploy

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1486593
Change-Id: Ie0c5cb5abff61d11b7a9278de6771fa008b69218

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-11 00:12:54.000000000', 'files': ['reference/tags/role_operator-interface.rst', 'reference/tags/index.rst', 'reference/tags/role_cloud-native-application.rst', 'reference/tags/role_base-compute-ring.rst', 'reference/tags/role_user-interface.rst'], 'message': "WIP - add some tags describing roles

This is a rough initial draft, adding four new tags along two axis.
I fully expect that it will be met with some disagreement, and would
like a discussion around both what is wrong and what is missing from
this proposal.

Covering some of the existing service projects' intended usage,
these two tags describe where in the stack an OpenStack service
fits:
- role:base-compute-ring
- role:cloud-native-application

Covering the intended consumer of user-facing projects, these two tags
describe whether the project targets cloud operators or cloud
application developers.
- role:user-interface
- role:operator-interface

Neither of the above axis are completely covered in the current
proposal. Eg, none of these tags would apply to swift, ironic, or
devstack.

Change-Id: I68955d0122884d3d351193347ca8d61410c232cb
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
WIP - add some tags describing roles

This is a rough initial draft, adding four new tags along two axis.
I fully expect that it will be met with some disagreement, and would
like a discussion around both what is wrong and what is missing from
this proposal.

Covering some of the existing service projects' intended usage,
these two tags describe where in the stack an OpenStack service
fits:
- role:base-compute-ring
- role:cloud-native-application

Covering the intended consumer of user-facing projects, these two tags
describe whether the project targets cloud operators or cloud
application developers.
- role:user-interface
- role:operator-interface

Neither of the above axis are completely covered in the current
proposal. Eg, none of these tags would apply to swift, ironic, or
devstack.

Change-Id: I68955d0122884d3d351193347ca8d61410c232cb

[{'created': '2015-09-18 00:13:41.000000000', 'files': ['heat/engine/resources/template_resource.py'], 'message': 'Only write to template files if template data changes

commit_message:
Only write to template files if template data changes

Currently the template data is assigned to the files dict regardless
of whether the data has changed or not.

This has no consequence on Liberty, but the files dict in Kilo
and Juno is a sqlalchemy MutableDict so these assignments are triggering
updates to the raw_template table. These updates are even triggered for
calls to heat resource-list. With large raw_template records this can make
heat unusable.

Therefore this fix is presented here as having no effect (and being
harmless) to git master, but high priority backports for Kilo and Juno.

Change-Id: Ibb714a9c5dc9f6879ff108419127da985a57897b
Closes-Bug: #1494108

commit_message:
diskfile: make get_ondisk_files return a dict

get_ondisk_files gathers a dict with more info than just the set
of data, ts and/or meta files, but only returns the
set of files to the DiskFile class. The other info
in the dict may be useful policy specific implementations, so
return the whole dict.

Also, refactor _get_ondisk_file to move duplicated code into the
BaseDiskFile open() method.

Change-Id: I7a17d26b7ed7f7c593f577332937793419c03cfa
Co-Authored-By: Paul Luse <paul.e.luse@intel.com>
Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>

Change-Id: If22bbaff89251e4e82a715170a48b4040f95c09f', 'number': 9}, {'created': '2015-07-08 00:28:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "WIP Generic image cache.

Note: Still needs a bunch of tests, but is otherwise mostly of working.

This introduces a new feature for backends to be able to use cached
glance images when creating volumes from images. If enabled, and the
cinder internal tenant is configured, it will create a minimal sized
clone of a volume the first time it is downloaded from glance. A new db
table ‘image_volume_cache’ tracks these volumes, which are owned by the
Cinder internal tenant. The original will then be extended to full size.
Any subsequent requests to create a volume from an image will be able
to do a volume clone from the image-volume cache entry instead of
downloading the image data from glance again.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if size is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes do not
take any quota from *any* user. They are only limited by the cache size
configuration options.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like ‘image_volume_cache.miss’, ‘image_volume_cache.hit’,
and ‘image_volume_cache.evict’. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the ‘image_id’
and ‘host’ fields.


DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it.

Implements: image-volume-cache
Change-Id: If22bbaff89251e4e82a715170a48b4040f95c09f", 'number': 10}, {'created': '2015-07-08 02:14:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "WIP Generic image cache.

Note: Still needs a bunch of tests, but is otherwise mostly of working.

This introduces a new feature for backends to be able to use cached
glance images when creating volumes from images. If enabled, and the
cinder internal tenant is configured, it will create a minimal sized
clone of a volume the first time it is downloaded from glance. A new db
table ‘image_volume_cache’ tracks these volumes, which are owned by the
Cinder internal tenant. The original will then be extended to full size.
Any subsequent requests to create a volume from an image will be able
to do a volume clone from the image-volume cache entry instead of
downloading the image data from glance again.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if size is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes do not
take any quota from *any* user. They are only limited by the cache size
configuration options.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like ‘image_volume_cache.miss’, ‘image_volume_cache.hit’,
and ‘image_volume_cache.evict’. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the ‘image_id’
and ‘host’ fields.

DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it.

Implements: image-volume-cache
Change-Id: If22bbaff89251e4e82a715170a48b4040f95c09f
", 'number': 11}, {'created': '2015-07-08 20:16:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "WIP Generic image cache.

Note: Still needs a bunch of tests, but is otherwise mostly of working.

This introduces a new feature for backends to be able to use cached
glance images when creating volumes from images. If enabled, and the
cinder internal tenant is configured, it will create a minimal sized
clone of a volume the first time it is downloaded from glance. A new db
table ‘image_volume_cache’ tracks these volumes, which are owned by the
Cinder internal tenant. The original will then be extended to full size.
Any subsequent requests to create a volume from an image will be able
to do a volume clone from the image-volume cache entry instead of
downloading the image data from glance again.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if space is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes do not
take any quota from *any* user. They are only limited by the cache size
configuration options.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like ‘image_volume_cache.miss’, ‘image_volume_cache.hit’,
and ‘image_volume_cache.evict’. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the ‘image_id’
and ‘host’ fields.

DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it.

Implements: image-volume-cache

before uploading the volume to glance.

will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes will
use quota for the internal tenant.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like ‘image_volume_cache.miss’, ‘image_volume_cache.hit’,
and ‘image_volume_cache.evict’. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the ‘image_id’
and ‘host’ fields.

This introduces a new feature for backends to be able to use cached

If enabled, and the cinder internal tenant is configured, it will
create a minimal sized clone of a volume the first time it is
downloaded from glance. A new db table ‘image_volume_cache’ tracks

volume right before uploading the volume to glance. This version
however does not aim to do more than add the initial framework and
help with subsequent image downloads. There are certainly more
improvements that can be done over time on top of this.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

notifications like ‘image_volume_cache.miss’, ‘image_volume_cache.hit’,
and ‘image_volume_cache.evict’. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to

", 'number': 24}, {'created': '2015-07-29 16:26:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Generic image-volume cache

This introduces a new feature for backends to be able to use cached
glance images when creating volumes from images.

If enabled, and the cinder internal tenant is configured, it will
create a minimal sized clone of a volume the first time it is
downloaded from glance. A new db table ‘image_volume_cache’ tracks
these volumes, which are owned by the Cinder internal tenant. The
original will then be extended to full size. Any subsequent requests to
create a volume from an image will be able to do a volume clone from
the image-volume cache entry instead of downloading the image data from
glance again.

This functionality requires an image to have its ‘virtual_size’ set in
its Glance metadata. With the v2 glance API certain workflows to create
images will automatically set this, but for others it will require a
manual step to set the ‘virtual_size’ property on the image.

Future changes to Glance and Cinder can make this more automated to
set the virtual size any chance we can. For example when creating a
volume from image though the default driver implementation in Cinder
we actually get the virtual size from a qemu-img command. We could
potentially set it on the image automatically for a user. This is
however something to be done on top of the initial cache functionality
and would be added later on in another change.

In the future we could create an entry upon creating an image from a
volume right before uploading the volume to glance. This version
however does not aim to do more than add the initial framework and
help with subsequent image downloads. There are certainly more
improvements that can be done over time on top of this.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if space is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes will
use quota for the internal tenant.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like ‘image_volume_cache.miss’, ‘image_volume_cache.hit’,
and ‘image_volume_cache.evict’. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the ‘image_id’
and ‘host’ fields.

DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it. The three new config options should also be
documented somewhere: ‘image_volume_cache_enabled’,
’image_volume_cache_max_size_gb’, ‘image_volume_cache_max_size_count’

Implements: image-volume-cache
Change-Id: If22bbaff89251e4e82a715170a48b4040f95c09f", 'number': 25}, {'created': '2015-07-30 23:06:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Generic image-volume cache

This introduces a new feature for backends to be able to use cached
glance images when creating volumes from images.

If enabled, and the cinder internal tenant is configured, it will
create a minimal sized clone of a volume the first time it is
downloaded from glance. A new db table ‘image_volume_cache’ tracks
these volumes, which are owned by the Cinder internal tenant. The
original will then be extended to full size. Any subsequent requests to
create a volume from an image will be able to do a volume clone from
the image-volume cache entry instead of downloading the image data from
glance again.

This functionality requires an image to have its ‘virtual_size’ set in
its Glance metadata. With the v2 glance API certain workflows to create
images will automatically set this, but for others it will require a
manual step to set the ‘virtual_size’ property on the image.

Future changes to Glance and Cinder can make this more automated to
set the virtual size any chance we can. For example when creating a
volume from image though the default driver implementation in Cinder
we actually get the virtual size from a qemu-img command. We could
potentially set it on the image automatically for a user. This is
however something to be done on top of the initial cache functionality
and would be added later on in another change.

In the future we could create an entry upon creating an image from a
volume right before uploading the volume to glance. This version
however does not aim to do more than add the initial framework and
help with subsequent image downloads. There are certainly more
improvements that can be done over time on top of this.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if space is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are

its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if space is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes will
use quota for the internal tenant.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like ‘image_volume_cache.miss’, ‘image_volume_cache.hit’,
and ‘image_volume_cache.evict’. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the ‘image_id’
and ‘host’ fields.

DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it. The three new config options should also be
documented somewhere: ‘image_volume_cache_enabled’,
’image_volume_cache_max_size_gb’, ‘image_volume_cache_max_size_count’

Change-Id: If22bbaff89251e4e82a715170a48b4040f95c09f", 'number': 35}, {'created': '2015-08-13 17:30:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Generic image-volume cache

This introduces a new feature for backends to be able to use cached
glance images when creating volumes from images.

If enabled, and the cinder internal tenant is configured, it will
create a minimal sized clone of a volume the first time it is
downloaded from glance. A new db table ‘image_volume_cache’ tracks
these volumes, which are owned by the Cinder internal tenant. The
original will then be extended to full size. Any subsequent requests to
create a volume from an image will be able to do a volume clone from
the image-volume cache entry instead of downloading the image data from
glance again.

This functionality requires an image to have its ‘virtual_size’ set in
its Glance metadata. With the v2 glance API certain workflows to create
images will automatically set this, but for others it will require a
manual step to set the ‘virtual_size’ property on the image.

Future changes to Glance and Cinder can make this more automated to
set the virtual size any chance we can. For example when creating a
volume from image though the default driver implementation in Cinder
we actually get the virtual size from a qemu-img command. We could
potentially set it on the image automatically for a user. This is
however something to be done on top of the initial cache functionality
and would be added later on in another change.

In the future we could create an entry upon creating an image from a
volume right before uploading the volume to glance. This version
however does not aim to do more than add the initial framework and
help with subsequent image downloads. There are certainly more
improvements that can be done over time on top of this.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if space is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes will
use quota for the internal tenant.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like ‘image_volume_cache.miss’, ‘image_volume_cache.hit’,
and ‘image_volume_cache.evict’. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the ‘image_id’
and ‘host’ fields.

DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it. The three new config options should also be
documented somewhere: ‘image_volume_cache_enabled’,
’image_volume_cache_max_size_gb’, ‘image_volume_cache_max_size_count’

", 'number': 46}, {'created': '2015-08-26 16:20:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Generic image-volume cache

This introduces a new feature for backends to be able to use cached
glance images when creating volumes from images.

If enabled, and the cinder internal tenant is configured, it will
create a minimal sized clone of a volume the first time it is
downloaded from glance. A new db table ‘image_volume_cache’ tracks
these volumes, which are owned by the Cinder internal tenant. The
original will then be extended to full size. Any subsequent requests to
create a volume from an image will be able to do a volume clone from
the image-volume cache entry instead of downloading the image data from
glance again.

In the future we could create an entry upon creating an image from a
volume right before uploading the volume to glance. This version
however does not aim to do more than add the initial framework and
help with subsequent image downloads. There are certainly more
improvements that can be done over time on top of this.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if space is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes will
use quota for the internal tenant.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like ‘image_volume_cache.miss’, ‘image_volume_cache.hit’,
and ‘image_volume_cache.evict’. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the ‘image_id’
and ‘host’ fields.

DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it. The three new config options should also be
documented somewhere: ‘image_volume_cache_enabled’,
’image_volume_cache_max_size_gb’, ‘image_volume_cache_max_size_count’

Co-Authored-By: Tomoki Sekiyama <tomoki.sekiyama@hds.com>

Implements: image-volume-cache

commit_message:
Generic image-volume cache

This introduces a new feature for backends to be able to use cached
glance images when creating volumes from images.

If enabled, and the cinder internal tenant is configured, it will
create a minimal sized clone of a volume the first time it is
downloaded from glance. A new db table ‘image_volume_cache’ tracks
these volumes, which are owned by the Cinder internal tenant. The
original will then be extended to full size. Any subsequent requests to
create a volume from an image will be able to do a volume clone from
the image-volume cache entry instead of downloading the image data from
glance again.

In the future we could create an entry upon creating an image from a
volume right before uploading the volume to glance. This version
however does not aim to do more than add the initial framework and
help with subsequent image downloads. There are certainly more
improvements that can be done over time on top of this.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if space is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes will
use quota for the internal tenant.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like ‘image_volume_cache.miss’, ‘image_volume_cache.hit’,
and ‘image_volume_cache.evict’. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the ‘image_id’
and ‘host’ fields.

DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it. The three new config options should also be
documented somewhere: ‘image_volume_cache_enabled’,
’image_volume_cache_max_size_gb’, ‘image_volume_cache_max_size_count’

Co-Authored-By: Tomoki Sekiyama <tomoki.sekiyama@hds.com>

Implements: blueprint image-volume-cache
Change-Id: If22bbaff89251e4e82a715170a48b4040f95c09f

commit_message:
controller hieradata: cleanup default_floating_pool

default_floating_pool is now a paramter in ::nova class.
Let's use it properly.

Change-Id: Idffe3e9cab1c8eb306a43b6c36a28ea51331c816

commit_message:

Add unit tests for signature_utils class

This patch adds unit tests for the signature_utils class,
which adds image signing functionality to Glance.

commit_message:
live-migration: Logs exception if operation failed

Live-migration can fail silently, without proper logging, making it
hard to determine the cause of the failure.

Closes-Bug: #1489874

Change-Id: Ib70dafd6fe2658ae9a1a43d177f4ed2c99a10c04

commit_message:
Use admin context in octavia driver, improve logs

When polling for the status of a load balancer in octavia, the context created
by the plugin was being used.  Since the polling takes place in a thread, that
context can have some unexpected behavior.  It is better to create an admin
context in the thread because it definitely exists in that thread.

Also improve debug logging in the octavia driver and the successful and failed
completion helper methods in the mixins.

Change-Id: I6f64c95d89876c9d1d19076a4fe7e3006a0df5e0
Closes-Bug: #1497823

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-15 21:04:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Relax newly imposed sql driver restriction for domain config

The first implementation of the domain config API introduced a
new restrction in terms of which identity drivers could be SQL
backed (to avoid potential multi-process race conditions). This
restriction specified that only the default domain could be SQL
backed.

This patch resolves these issues and hence enusres the restrictions
in terms of SQL identity drivers are the same as the original config
file based domain condif approach (i.e. only one driver can be SQL
backend, but it can be any for any given domain).

THIS PATCH IS STILL WORK IN PROGRESS

Fixes bug 1450344

Change-Id: Id1b4415cb5f263dc7afd9e25bd0da2b667f1c90a
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2015-06-19 12:09:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Relax newly imposed sql driver restriction for domain config

The first implementation of the domain config API introduced a
new restriction in terms of which identity drivers could be SQL
backed (to avoid potential multi-process race conditions). This
restriction specified that only the default domain could be SQL
backed.

This patch resolves these issues and hence ensures the restrictions
in terms of SQL identity drivers are the same as the original config
file based approach (i.e. only one driver can be SQL backend, but
it can be any for any given domain).

Since this patch is likely to be backported to Kilo, it uses one
of the SQL placeholder migrations.

Fixes bug 1450344

commit_message:
Relax newly imposed sql driver restriction for domain config

The first implementation of the domain config API introduced a
new restriction in terms of which identity drivers could be SQL
backend (to avoid potential multi-process race conditions). This
restriction specified that only the default domain could be SQL
backend.

This patch resolves these issues and hence ensures the restrictions
in terms of SQL identity drivers are the same as the original config
file based approach (i.e. only one driver can be SQL backend, but
it can be for any given domain).

Although this patch changes the V8 driver interface, this is for
the domain_config backend which is still marked as experimental.

Closes-Bug: #1450344
Change-Id: Id1b4415cb5f263dc7afd9e25bd0da2b667f1c90a

commit_message:
Add Cisco IMC PXE Driver

Current drivers only allow for control of UCS servers via either IPMI or
UCSM, the Cisco UCS C-Series operating in standalone mode can also be
controlled via CIMC using its http/s XML API. This provides finer
control over the server than IPMI can, and doesn't require the extra
infrastructure that UCSM needs.

Change-Id: Ibd39040e3d7e82a87960d33150750433beb2453b
Implements: blueprint cisco-imc-pxe-driver

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-08-19 07:37:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Hyper-V: Implements detach_interface method

Neutron events have been added to nova. If the event
"network-vif-unplugged" is received, the nova compute manager
will proceed to call the compute driver's detach_interface method.
The mentioned method is not implemented in the HyperVDriver,
causing errors.

On Windows Hyper-V / Server 2012 R2 (kernel version 6.4), vNICs
can be attached / detached while the VM are running, if the VM
is generation 2.

Adds detach_interface method implementation.

Co-Authored-By: Adelina Tuvenie <atuvenie@cloudbasesolutions.com>

Closes-Bug: #1486410
Change-Id: I6e0f6a8373810560ae2fadc99b7dd57c06391c96

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Implements attach_interface and detach_interface method

Neutron events have been added to nova. If the event
"network-vif-unplugged" is received, the nova compute manager
will proceed to call the compute driver's detach_interface method.
The mentioned method is not implemented in the HyperVDriver,
causing errors.

On Windows Hyper-V / Server Threshold (kernel version 10.0), vNICs
can be attached / detached while the VM are running, if the VM
is generation 2.

Adds attach_interface and detach_interface method implementations.

Co-Authored-By: Adelina Tuvenie <atuvenie@cloudbasesolutions.com>

Closes-Bug: #1486410
Change-Id: I6e0f6a8373810560ae2fadc99b7dd57c06391c96

commit_message:
Remove "shelved_image_id" key from instance system metadata

In the unit test case "test_unshelve_instance_schedule_and_rebuild_volume_backed
", set the "shelved_image_id" to the instance system metadata,
it tests the instance boot from image, not boot from volume.
So it needs to remove "shelved_image_id" from the  metadata,
and remove "image_api.get" mock method.

Change-Id: Ie501acaaa1c961a4b6f1f4ea9726a5b11b0de709
Closes-Bug: #1485429
Signed-off-by: Xiaowei Qian <qianxw.fnst@cn.fujitsu.com>

subject: Fix reconnecting to libvirt
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-09-21 14:14:43.000000000', 'files': ['ceilometer/compute/virt/libvirt/inspector.py'], 'message': "Fix reconnecting to libvirt

The libvirt inspector may can't inspect data from libvirt on some occasions after
libvirtd is restarted, though we have reconnecting logic. When this occurs, it will
raise libvirt.VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR instead of libvirt.VIR_ERR_SYSTEM_ERROR in
reconnecting logic. This results compute agent no longer reconnects to libvirt, and
fails to inspect data any more. This patch is just updated to deal with INTERNAL_ERROR.

Change-Id: Ifbd754cb050ec7e364d17fea3b32191da1e22ef5
Closes-bug: #1498013
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Fix reconnecting to libvirt

The libvirt inspector may can't inspect data from libvirt on some occasions after
libvirtd is restarted, though we have reconnecting logic. When this occurs, it will
raise libvirt.VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR instead of libvirt.VIR_ERR_SYSTEM_ERROR in
reconnecting logic. This results compute agent no longer reconnects to libvirt, and
fails to inspect data any more. This patch is just updated to deal with INTERNAL_ERROR.

Change-Id: Ifbd754cb050ec7e364d17fea3b32191da1e22ef5
Closes-bug: #1498013

commit_message:
Removing "skip" decorators for some OpenStack actions tests

Bug #1422725 has been fixed and now there is no need to skip
test_heat_actions and test_neutron_actions tests. This patch
removes "skip" decorators for these tests.

Depends-on: I745b9fd7fa2a36bbe97e17e3441f9cda4b8ea33f

Change-Id: Ib53054a68cec6b2412c088f9b149e173755a19b2

subject: Change recon_lock_path to /var/lock
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-09-21 18:45:21.000000000', 'files': ['rpc_deployment/roles/swift_object/templates/object-server.conf.j2', 'rpc_deployment/roles/swift_account/templates/account-server.conf.j2', 'rpc_deployment/inventory/group_vars/swift_all.yml', 'rpc_deployment/roles/swift_container/templates/container-server.conf.j2'], 'message': "Change recon_lock_path to /var/lock

The Swift configuration item [filter:recon]/recon_lock_path is set to
'/var/lock/swift' by openstack-ansible in the appropriate configuration
files. The playbooks also create the directory if it does not exist. If
the host is rebooted the directory '/var/lock/swift' is missing and must
be recreated.

/var/lock (/run/lock) is a tmpfs and so the directory /var/lock/swift
will not persist between reboots.

Swift attempts to create a directory in the directory specified by
recon_lock_path however it does not recursively create any missing
parent directories.

This commit changes the value of [filter:recon]/recon_lock_path to that
set by Swift, '/var/lock'. This allows it to create the directory
'/var/lock/swift-recon-object-cron'. The creation of '/var/lock/swift'
is also removed from the playbooks.

Conflicts:
  playbooks/roles/os_swift/tasks/swift_pre_install.yml
  playbooks/roles/os_swift/templates/account-server.conf.j2
  playbooks/roles/os_swift/templates/container-server.conf.j2
  playbooks/roles/os_swift/templates/object-server.conf.j2

Change-Id: I714367b02c7cf961e9e0bdee4e41f9e4e105b088
Closes-bug: #1496117
(cherry picked from commit 176107aa3026ce03a09bd9a62e7a100e58d2cccc)
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Change recon_lock_path to /var/lock

The Swift configuration item [filter:recon]/recon_lock_path is set to
'/var/lock/swift' by openstack-ansible in the appropriate configuration
files. The playbooks also create the directory if it does not exist. If
the host is rebooted the directory '/var/lock/swift' is missing and must
be recreated.

/var/lock (/run/lock) is a tmpfs and so the directory /var/lock/swift
will not persist between reboots.

Swift attempts to create a directory in the directory specified by
recon_lock_path however it does not recursively create any missing
parent directories.

This commit changes the value of [filter:recon]/recon_lock_path to that
set by Swift, '/var/lock'. This allows it to create the directory
'/var/lock/swift-recon-object-cron'. The creation of '/var/lock/swift'
is also removed from the playbooks.

Conflicts:
  playbooks/roles/os_swift/tasks/swift_pre_install.yml
  playbooks/roles/os_swift/templates/account-server.conf.j2
  playbooks/roles/os_swift/templates/container-server.conf.j2
  playbooks/roles/os_swift/templates/object-server.conf.j2

Change-Id: I714367b02c7cf961e9e0bdee4e41f9e4e105b088
Closes-bug: #1496117
(cherry picked from commit 176107aa3026ce03a09bd9a62e7a100e58d2cccc)

commit_message:
devref: Add bug handling description to developer reference

The bug handling in nova is described over a few wiki pages. It also
missed some information a new developer would need to understand the
process. An adoption and review of the process with the core reviewers
and the bug-supervisors is hard to do.

This patch set adds a page to the developer reference and should be
the "single source of truth" one needs to read to be able to
participate in the bug handling process of nova.

Partially Implements: blueprint devref-refresh-liberty

Change-Id: I4c306e4201fecc17aee2714e3075b5d1d291a322
Depends-On: Ia699fd1965b475f2633ecfc555bc766eb5aa3404

[{'created': '2015-05-28 07:52:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Volume status management during migration

The initial migration_status is None, meaning no migration has been
done. Migration_status 'error' means the previous migration fails.
Migration_status 'success' means the previous migration succeeds.

The volume status should be set to 'migrating' during migration and
goes back to its original status after migration.

Change-Id: Ia86421f2d6fce61dcfeb073f8e7b9c9dde517373
Partially-implements-blueprint: migration-improvement

", 'number': 11}, {'created': '2015-06-09 05:37:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Volume status management during migration

The initial migration_status is None, meaning no migration has been
done. Migration_status 'error' means the previous migration fails.
Migration_status 'success' means the previous migration succeeds.

The volume status should be set to 'maintenance' during migration and
goes back to its original status after migration, if the admin issues
the migrate command with the flag --force.

All the actions, including attach, detach, etc, are not allowed
when the volume is in 'maintenance' mode.

Change-Id: Ia86421f2d6fce61dcfeb073f8e7b9c9dde517373
Partially-implements-blueprint: migration-improvement

", 'number': 28}, {'created': '2015-07-10 04:34:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Volume status management during migration

The initial migration_status is None, meaning no migration has been
done. Migration_status 'error' means the previous migration failed.
Migration_status 'success' means the previous migration succeeded.

If the --force flag is used, the volume status should be set to
'maintenance' during migration and goes back to its original status
after migration. Otherwise, if the --force flag is not used or set
to True, the volume status will remain the same as its original
status.

All the actions, including attach, detach, etc, are not allowed
when the volume is in 'maintenance' mode. If it is not in maintenance
mode, the migration can be terminated if other requests
are issued, e.g. attach.

DocImpact
APIImpact The --force flag has been added into the API, telling the
volume to change the status to 'maintenance' or not.

Change-Id: Ia86421f2d6fce61dcfeb073f8e7b9c9dde517373
Partially-implements-blueprint: migration-improvement

", 'number': 32}, {'created': '2015-07-13 07:38:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Volume status management during migration

The initial migration_status is None, meaning no migration has been
done. Migration_status 'error' means the previous migration failed.
Migration_status 'success' means the previous migration succeeded.

If the --force flag is used, the volume status should be set to
'maintenance' during migration and goes back to its original status
after migration. Otherwise, if the --force flag is not used or set
to True, the volume status will remain the same as its original
status.

All the actions, including attach, detach, etc, are not allowed
when the volume is in 'maintenance' mode. If it is not in maintenance
mode, the migration can be terminated if other requests
are issued, e.g. attach.

DocImpact
APIImpact The --force flag has been added into the API, telling the
volume to change the status to 'maintenance' or not.
